displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: So you have to have loose bowels. That means – Patient: That’s what I’m talkin’ about. Doctor: Soft. Stool softeners. Patient: Stool softeners. Doctor: Absolutely. Patient: They ain’t workin’ like they’re supposed to, doc! Doctor: There’s no way that we can get you not pooping correctly because there’s so many different types of laxatives out there – Patient: Yeah, well. Doctor: You just need to take more. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Yeah. You just don’t have enough – Patient: Enough.

Family Member: Right, but I’m just… Doctor: Yeah, the standard… Family Member: Are there different types of… Doctor: Yes, there are different… Family Member: Okay. Doctor: …types of chemotherapy. The standard one for… Patient: For what I have. Doctor: …this one, for prostate cancer, is to start with Taxotere or Docetaxel and that would be what you would get. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: One of the things to consider is you know we do have a new hormonal therapy that is being tested and that would be one potential option for you to look into. Patient: Is that a study? Doctor: Yes.

Patient: And what is a PSMA? Doctor: That’s literally like a target. It’s like a PSA. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s a target on your cells and we try to go after it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That sounds like fun. Patient: Wow. Doctor: And you know in Europe it’s really been done for imaging. Like you really try to oh you do the PSMA scan so you’re trying to find where the cancer is. The struggle you know for us for the drug part is getting enough of a drug level to be able to kill the cell so Patient: Yeah. Doctor: that’s kind of like what this is. So I hope we get a spot but I already told M_____ to stick her foot out. Patient: But you know I mean I really have nothing to complain about because um it’s eleven and a half years since I was diagnosed. Doctor: That’s incredible. Patient: And um all things being considered I guess eleven and half a years ago I didn’t think I’d be here right now.

Family Member 1: In the last two weeks. But we knew it was all for your spine, been that for two years. Doctor: Great. Sorry about that. I just needed to check. Huh, huh, so we also, you know, checked your molecular stuff and there wasn’t anything that jumped out, huh, that says that we have something that we could add a treatment to. You crying? What’s that about? Patient: Dying. Dying. Doctor: Do you feel like you’re dying or just that’s-? Patient: Well you know it’s going to happen. Doctor: Okay. Huh, you have questions, or just-? Patient: I just want to be around a little bit longer, that’s all. Doctor: Well, our hope is that as well. Huh, my sense is, you know, these next drugs we, huh, huh, can get you a little bit more mileage, and you still haven’t had chemotherapy, which could get you some mileage. Huh, there’s an IV radiation drug that can get you a mileage. Most of it’s kicking the can down the street. Huh, we’ve got clinical trials at different points of new drugs, different drugs, combinations of drugs, huh, that we could think about. Huh, yes, so there’s a lot of things out there. It’s a matter of how much you want to go through, the rest of your body, your heart, the other things can get through because the next two drugs, we pick one of them. Huh, one of them is abiraterone, which is probably the cheaper of the two. It’s just gone generic. That doesn’t mean it’s cheap. Huh, but it’s about eleven, twelve thousand dollars a month. Huh, we check with your insurance carrier to see how much they cover. Huh, are you, huh, Medicare, Medicaid, huh, regular insurance, or-? Patient: Right now. Family Member: The next couple of days he’s regular insurance, but he’s going to get Medicare the first of March. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And that will help out. Patient: March first I start Medicare plus a supplement.

Patient: Yeah. Could we do it Thursday afternoon? Doctor: Sure, yeah. Family Member: It’s just an echo… Patient: How long does it take – to do that ? Doctor: It’s about, not a very long time, but it would mean that I would just need to, we would need to coordinate the echo appointment and all that- that’s why I’m just asking you for Patient: Thursday afternoon. Doctor: -a few days. that work out well for you Because… Patient: Thursday afternoon. We’re going to Canada on Saturday morning. Doctor: Okay and then next week. Patient: Closer than Vancouver. Doctor: Fair enough. Next week anytime? Family Member: For the same thing?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Retired: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Retired

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: All right. Doctor: That’s probably the best. Healthcare Professional: As a matter of fact, I’m going to go get schedule; I’ll be right back. Doctor: Easiest, in some ways, yeah. Healthcare Professional: I’m going to go get POS. Doctor: So, so I think now you’re going to - Family Member: And if that happens, what if all of a sudden he spikes a fever and it happens at night, uh - Doctor: Right, yeah, yeah, that’s right. No, one-eight hundred _____. That is like a twenty-four-hour line. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You can do it yourself, but then you’re flustered. It’s a little bit complicated, - Family Member: Yes, yes. Doctor: So that’s why I prefer; you know I tell people - Patient: Right, yes.

Family Member: I’ve noticed that when he gets enough rest- Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He seems to tolerate the next day better. Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: Even if he’s uncomfortable, he’s not irritable and tired – Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But the lack of rest contributes to a lot of issues for both of us. Doctor: Um hum. Sure. Yeah. That will help with uh you feeling better during the day, too. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Right. I see what you mean. Okay. So let me have S___ come in – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: -and give you a copy of the consent.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the good news is there are a number of different treatments. Uh, you know, this one is worth a try, but otherwise there are hormonal pills or other really effective things, too, that we can use outside of the study. Okay? Family Member: So, we don’t have to go through the study? Doctor: So what we’re going to ask is we will make a request, as long as you’re okay with it, to see if the study is accepting new people and if, you know, we’ll send you a case description in. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: As long as but I need your okay for that. Patient: Okay. Family Member: That’s fine. Doctor: And if I have that, uh, if they say that, yes, we can go ahead, we’ll let you know and we’ll have them come back to do all the consenting and all of that procedure. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If, however, they say, not right now, it’s too much, if it’s a week or two, I’m okay with waiting. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: If it’s going to be a month or more, I don’t think then we should wait. We should look into other things.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you know the clinical trials and also the clinical experience do suggest that when you combine standard hormone therapy with chemotherapy or standard hormone therapy with newer type of hormone therapy called (novel) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. But but again, I don’t want you to go into that thinking that it’s going to increase the chance of a cure. The cure rate is still you know pretty close to zero percent and that it increases the length of time that that systemic therapy works. Patient: Okay. And see, that that that’s my concern at this point. Um you know um you think in terms of the reason I keep pushing hormonal so far back is because I know that’s a proven method - Doctor: Yeah. It is - Patient: - or a proven therapy that will slow the progression. So I know that. So thinking in terms of that uh if there was something else that was being done before we actually hit that, that’s almost like saying, “This is my little (laughs) Family Member: Right, right. Patient: You know to hold, you know while I try other things. Of course I have to go relying on your experience. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Uh hum. Patient: And that’s your level of expertise what you’re doing. You’re the oncologist. You know so I’m going to have to weigh… Doctor: Yeah. Sure.

Family Member: Um Hmm. Doctor: study is, uh, a pharmaceutical company Family Member: Okay. Doctor: that is developing this drug. Uh, so, they’re the ones that are behind it. Um. So, this, uh, Patient: Mmm. Doctor: That makes it easier. But we probably will need you to come in, and then they check, uh, blood tests one day just to see what the levels are, and, uh, what dose is the right amount of dose. Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: Um. So, let me, uh, check in with I_ to see if she needs to follow with you, uh, because we’ll just stay on drug for now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I put the order in for the blood test. I need to just check to make sure that, with the holiday, that if I draw it, it’s not gonna get lost or be not usable because, uh, nobody’s here to work on it. Patient: Right. Doctor: They only run the test once a week. So, if they’re aware it’s coming today and they run it next Monday, then you’re golden.

Patient: I haven’t talked to him. Doctor: No but when they did the testing? Patient: Oh he said it’s worse. Doctor: It’s worse? Patient: A little worse, yeah. Doctor: Really? Patient: Yeah. The um… Doctor: So the strength was worse? Patient: Right. Doctor: That was worse. That would be the reason then to do… Patient: Right, right. Doctor: …you know to lean towards surgery. Because if it’s going to take the pressure off the nerve…

Family Member: Even though when they get him they go to the Docetaxal? Doctor: Now, Oh, well, from a chemo standpoint we might have to negotiate that. For sure if you get on the high-dose vitamin C one that is more labor intensive because the chemo is once every three months, not three months, once every three weeks. He got hopeful there for a minute. No, sorry, once every three weeks but the vitamin C is twice a week because it’s at such a high dose. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Well, think about normal stuff you would pop every day you’d almost have to take it multiple times a day to get that dose. This would be the super high one so you’re here like twice a week for like weeks and months. I mean we hope it’s that long because that means it’s working, but yeah, that’s a bit of a slightly draining on that one Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but I have a lot of people who just want their hands on high-dose vitamin C because this is you know, formulated differently than just sort of generic stuff. This is really done with the right, you know, it’s made by a company that’s sort of a spinoff of Hopkins so it’s a very well-regulated product. Um, but, can I tell you that if you’re on placebo you still have to be here? Yeah, because I don’t know who’s getting what. So, the three of us would be fast friends for weeks. Every day it’d be like hello, hello. Just take your name and tape it on an infusion area and you’ll see M____ and S____ all the time. So, that’s one but we’ll work on that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, we might need, if it’s something that frequent, we might need a port. Yeah, that’s a lot of beating up on you. You know, once every three weeks Patient: Right, Right. Doctor: you can get away with that and it’s like an hour but if you’re here twice a week it’s pretty painful. Patient: That’s possible that I don’t have to do that, right? Doctor: Well, you could always say no. You could say listen, I just want the chemo and I don’t want the vitamin C trial, just you know forget it and we would just do straight chemo. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah, I didn’t imagine, no idea. Doctor: Yeah. No. I agree. Yeah. So I think you should consider going on the study because that is our only chance, at least in the U.S., of getting on the medication. If you don’t, we are no better off than what we started with. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But now is a good time to consider the study because your cancer is not going crazy. Okay? Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? It’s only the PSA is inching up, but nothing else is getting worse. Patient: So I’ll only be in Texas for now long? Doctor: One or two days. Patient: A couple of days? Doctor: Yeah. The scan takes literally two hours. Patient: Stay, stay in the hospital or is-? Doctor: No. I think they put you in a hotel.

Family Member: That’s all right. (doors closing) Patient: They are? Good. Family Member: you’re eating. Doctor: I know about one again. Patient: The first time I went that was at the beginning, just like taking a shot, a few days after that I was throwing up every day for four days. And I talked to your assistant on email, and he said to go to emergency, and so we went and the problem was I wasn’t urinating properly. So they put a catheter in. Doctor: Let me stop you one second. Let’s, let me review some of the paperwork – Patient: Sure. So you can concentrate. Doctor: So uh you’re still taking the Bicalutamide or have you finished that -- the Casodex? Patient: What is that? Doctor: Uh what the pill that you took two weeks before I gave you the shot. Family Member: Yes, that’s done. The hormone - Patient: Yeah, yeah, that’s -

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And those are probably words that we opt to use. Um, If you have testicle cancer we could say remission Patient: Yeah. Doctor: because then you don’t see anything. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: There’s nothing in the blood work all your scans are clean, then you can say wow I see nothing Patient: Okay. Doctor: so you’re fine. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So just wordsmithing, but enough for me Patient: Sure. Doctor: to make sure that we’re talking about this clearly. Patient: Sure.
